Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.
Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Guide students through a reading of Riddle Me This.
Dictate the following sentences for students to write, one at a time:
Lucky never barks when we walk in the park. Can you discard that small carton of milk?
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. Each riddle contains clues that will help students identify the missing word.

For the first reading, read the first riddle and have students read the second riddle. Invite volunteers to solve each riddle. Then have students reread the riddles in pairs, alternating lines. Partners can switch lines during the rereadings.
Prompt students to find all words with
spellings in the riddles and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.

These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.

These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.

Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week, have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the amount of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.

Guide students through a reading of Taxes Help Everyone.
Have students draw four boxes on a sheet of paper.
Ask them to write an important fact about taxes in each box.

Then ask them to use these facts to write a one or two sentence summary of the selection. Have students share their summaries orally with a partner before writing them to make sure they are clearly stated and brief.

My moms car needs a new ____.

Read: What Are Taxes Used For?
Guide students through a reading of What Are Taxes Used For?
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Create a Pie Chart
Have students draw and label a pie chart that identifies the favorite colors of the students in their class.

Read the title. Explain that this shows what taxes are used for by displaying, or showing, a pie chart. The pie chart shows how much of Greenfields tax money goes to each service. The pie chart has colors and percentages. The percent is on each wedge. Each wedge identifies a service to show what the taxes pay for.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the pie chart.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the pie chart.

As students reading skills develop, provide a wider range of books for them to select to read and take home for independent reading. Find books about U.S. government, national parks, and taxes to connect to this units big ideas.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
